title: Food Allergies and the Fall Season

content: Fall is here! People around you are enjoying pumpkin spice and hot chocolate. Guess what? People with allergies can enjoy the delicious treats as well. Food allergies may cause us to take additional steps, but it does not mean we cannot enjoy the season. Exchange cow’s milk for soy, almond, oat, or coconut milk, or simply water. Order some treats online from your favorite brands, or visit places that offer multiple options for your family. Grab a sweater, jump into the leaves, and enjoy the flavors of the season.
Fall festivals, fairs, and pumpkin patches can be fun for the entire family. Here are a few tips we use to make our experiences fun and stress-free.
bullets: Focus on the activity or event instead of food. We choose festivals that have more to offer besides snacks and treats. Examples include rides, games, music, and shows.
Bring your own snacks. This is my motto everywhere we go. It is a great practice for all moms, but a necessity for people with food allergies.
Stick to familiar foods. Popcorn without dairy and cider are our go-to favorites. Focusing on what we can eat helps create a positive mindset toward the options that are available.

sections.heading: Fall Family Traditions
content: Kids’ joys can be simple, and they typically want to spend time with family and/or friends. Some of our favorite fall traditions are raking and jumping in leaves, shopping at the farmers market, attending at least one football game, adding fall season décor, and most importantly, changing the smells in our home to pumpkin and apple scents. We have different traditions throughout the year because this takes the focus away from food. Although food is included, the experience is about much more. My girls, now ages 9 and 7, look forward to all of this and do not let me forget it, ha! Be sure to create your own traditions as well.

With a little creativity, many seasonal favorites can be enjoyed in allergen-free versions. For example, you can use gluten-free flour, dairy-free butter, dairy-free whipped cream, egg-free pie crust, or dairy-free milk. Oats or seeds can replace nuts in recipes, and pies can be made without eggs. Your favorite snickerdoodle and gingerbread cookies can be made with safe ingredients. Most importantly, my favorite – pumpkin – is not one of the top nine common allergens.

sections.heading: Thanksgiving Prep
content: Thanksgiving is the centerpiece of the fall season, and it’s one of the most food-centric holidays of the year. Planning ahead is crucial. Whether you're hosting or attending someone else’s celebration, it’s important to take steps to ensure a safe meal.

It is easier for us to host at home, but sometimes family cannot come to us or we simply want to go somewhere else. If you’re a guest, communicate with the host about your allergies and ask about ingredients in the dishes being served. Most importantly, offer to bring a dish that you know is safe for your family to eat. If you’re the host, and have people coming who have food allergies, be sure to get the complete list of their allergens. You may need to consider gluten-free dressing, dairy-free mashed potatoes, allergy-friendly sweet potato souffle, or nut-free desserts. Labeling dishes can also be helpful for guests with dietary restrictions.

content: The crisp, cool air of fall is a refreshing change from the heat of summer. It's a time to pull out cozy sweaters, scarves, and boots, and enjoy the outdoors in comfort. Cooler temperatures also make it an ideal time for enjoying warm drinks like hot apple cider or hot chocolate.

Navigating the fall season with food allergies requires a little extra attention, but it’s entirely possible to enjoy the flavors, events, and traditions without sacrificing safety. By preparing allergen-friendly versions of fall favorites, planning ahead for autumn events, and staying vigilant about potential allergens, you can make the most of this beautiful time of year. Whether you want to enjoy a pumpkin spice latte or make a trip to a local festival, food allergies don’t have to stand in the way of enjoying all that fall has to offer.
